question: When the Regulator is considering whether it may disqualify an auditor or actuary for a contravention, how should it apply the requirement to consider all circumstances to determine both whether to disqualify and the breadth of the disqualification across any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity (or a class of them)?
gold_answer: The Regulator’s permission to disqualify an auditor or actuary where it considers a contravention has occurred must be exercised through an assessment that takes into account all the circumstances of the case, both to decide whether disqualification is appropriate and to set the scope of any disqualification across any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or any particular class thereof [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e]. In applying that “all circumstances” approach, the Regulator should consider, among other factors, the nature and seriousness of the contravention and its effects; whether the contravention or any failure to disclose information to the Regulator has resulted in or is likely to result in loss to customers, damage to the reputation of the ADGM, or an increased risk that a firm, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity may be used for financial crime; and what remedial action the auditor or actuary has taken [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22]. It should also weigh any relevant professional-body disciplinary action and whether it adequately addresses the contravention, as well as the auditor’s or actuary’s previous compliance record and any prior relevant sanctions, to calibrate the breadth and intensity of the disqualification [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22].
target_text: If the Regulator considers that an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention of these Regulations, it may disqualify the auditor or actuary from being the auditor of, or (as the case may be), from acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or any particular class thereof.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has already made one compliant disclosure and then later talks again about forecast financial information based on a Production Target, what does it have to say in the later disclosure, and what information can it avoid repeating from the earlier Production Target disclosure?
gold_answer: In a later disclosure about forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, a Mining Reporting Entity can avoid repeating the full set of detailed Production Target disclosure information, but only if specific conditions are met. The later disclosure must refer back to the earlier disclosure that contained the required Production Target assumption information, and it must include a confirmation that all material assumptions used for the initial forecast financial information still apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. The earlier disclosure it references must have included the required content for a Production Target disclosure, including the material economic assumptions (or a statement that they are commercially sensitive plus the methodology used), all other material assumptions, and (if forecast commodity prices were used) a statement that the forecast pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds, as well as the proportions of the Production Target attributable to the specified reserve/resource categories and any Exploration Target component [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. Also, the later disclosure must still include an equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement when the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, and must do the same when the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: If an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 falls below the required Capital Resources level compared with its Capital Requirement, what must it do to tell the Regulator, and does it also need to follow up in writing?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 finds that its Capital Resources have fallen below 120% of its Capital Requirement, it has an immediate duty to notify the Regulator as soon as that condition occurs [#SRC:c08e86ed-69f1-4d9f-81bf-af5206de7e41]. The obligation is not limited to a rapid initial alert: it must also confirm the notification in writing, so there is a required written follow-up (or written confirmation) to the Regulator after the immediate notice [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]. In practical terms, the rule sets a clear trigger (Capital Resources below the 120% threshold), identifies exactly who it applies to (Authorised Persons in Categories 3B, 3C or 4), and requires two linked actions: immediate notification and written confirmation. Both steps are mandatory once the threshold is crossed, and both are directed to the Regulator.
source_text: An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement, in accordance with Rule 3.20.2.
target_text: Notifications to the Regulator. An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately and confirm in writing if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity prepares a disclosure under a Mining Reporting Standard, how must it address non-mandatory requirements—particularly where it does not fully comply with them—and what explanation must be included in the disclosure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is expected to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, even though those requirements are described as non-mandatory, and this expectation sits alongside the obligation to fully comply with all binding requirements in the same standards [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124]. If, in a particular disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard, it must not remain silent or rely on the non-mandatory label; instead, it must include an explicit statement within the disclosure explaining both how the disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement and why it differs [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f]. In practice, this means the disclosure should identify the specific non-mandatory requirement that is not met, describe the nature of the deviation (the “how”), and provide the rationale for the deviation (the “why”), thereby addressing the Regulator’s expectation of full compliance or a clear explanation of non-compliance [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] while satisfying the disclosure-level statement requirement [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f].
source_text: Rule 11.2.1(1) requires a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all binding requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard. The Regulator also expects a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, including, for example, Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code, or explain its non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2.
target_text: Requirements for all disclosures. Where a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in a Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must provide in its disclosure a statement as to how and why its disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard.

question: When a Listed Entity is determining whether it is prohibited from issuing or agreeing to issue Equity Securities above its calculated maximum without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities, how must it count fully paid Ordinary Securities, partly paid Securities, and Convertible Securities in the calculation, and what discretion does the Regulator have to alter that counting?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity is prohibited from issuing, or agreeing to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the prescribed calculation unless it first obtains the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. To apply that prohibition correctly, the Listed Entity must calculate the number of Equity Securities it “may issue or agree to issue” by applying the counting rules for different instruments: each fully paid Ordinary Security counts as one; each partly paid Security counts as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be paid up; and each Convertible Security counts as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be converted [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]. For any other type of Security, the count is determined as the Regulator may decide, with regard to ensuring holders of Ordinary Securities have an opportunity to vote on issues that may dilute their holdings or based on the Security’s characteristics [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]. These counting steps feed into the maximum-cap framework (including the “Relevant Issues” concept) that triggers the approval requirement when exceeded [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933].
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: Where an Authorised Person has a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class with an issue-specific external credit assessment that attracts a 150% risk weight, what risk weight must be applied to any unrated CR Exposure (long term or short term) to the same corporate, and how does this compare to the unrated corporate risk weight in the corporate asset class table?
gold_answer: If a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class has an issue-specific external credit assessment that attracts a 150% risk weight, the Authorised Person must apply a 150% risk weight to any unrated CR Exposure—whether long term or short term—to the same corporate [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad]. This is a specific linkage requirement that overrides the lower unrated corporate baseline shown in the corporate asset class table, which assigns 100% to “Unrated” exposures (subject to the stated rule cross-references) [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4]. Therefore, even though the table would ordinarily indicate 100% for an unrated corporate exposure, the presence of a 150% rated short term issue for the same corporate triggers a mandatory 150% treatment for any unrated exposure to that corporate. The Authorised Person should document that the higher 150% risk weight is applied because the rated short term exposure’s risk weight dictates the minimum treatment for the related unrated exposures to the same obligor.
source_text:
Corporate asset class. The risk weight for any CR Exposure in the corporate asset class that does not have an external credit assessment by a recognised external credit rating agency must be the risk weight determined in accordance with the table under Rule 4.12.13 or the risk weight that is applicable to an CR Exposure to the central government of the jurisdiction in which the corporate is incorporated or established, whichever is higher. If a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class with an issue specific external credit assessment:
(a)	attracts a risk weight of 50% or 100%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of not lower than 100% to any unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate; or
(b)	attracts a risk weight of 150%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of 150% to any unrated CR Exposure (whether long term or short term) to the same corporate.
target_text:
Corporate asset class. Subject to Rules 4.12.14 and 4.12.15, an Authorised Person must risk weight any CR Exposure in the corporate asset class in accordance with the following table:
Risk Weights for the corporate asset class
/Table Start

Credit Quality Grade	1	2	3	4	5	6	Unrated
Risk Weight	20%	50%	100%	100%	150%	150%	100%

/Table End

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s Production Target for an operating mine is built only from Ore Reserves (or Ore Reserves plus Measured Mineral Resources, and any Indicated Mineral Resources are not what makes the project viable), can it skip the required information about the assumptions behind the Production Target, like material economic assumptions and other material assumptions?
gold_answer: In the operating-mine scenarios described—where the Production Target is wholly based on Ore Reserves, or on Ore Reserves together with Measured Mineral Resources, or on Ore Reserves with Measured and/or Indicated Mineral Resources provided the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability—the Mining Reporting Entity has a specific permission that its disclosure is not required to comply with the identified compliance requirement referenced in the SOURCE [#SRC:1d86427d-4a34-4179-bd16-1f64e7ef8560]. However, when the Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure pursuant to the TARGET obligation, it still has to include the required assumption-related content: it must address the assumptions used to determine the Production Target by providing all material economic assumptions, or (if it considers them commercially sensitive) a statement that they are commercially sensitive along with an explanation of the methodology used to determine them, and it must also include all other material assumptions utilised [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. So, the SOURCE creates a conditional carve-out from one compliance requirement, but the TARGET still imposes mandatory assumption disclosures for disclosures made under that obligation.
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure is not required to comply with Rule 11.8.3 where a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based upon:
(1)	Ore Reserves;
(2)	a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources; or
(3)	a combination of Ore Reserves; and
(a)	Measured Mineral Resources; and/or
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources, provided that the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability.
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:

(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: If an Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank or the European Commission, what risk weight must it apply, and when can it recognise the CRM effect of a Credit Derivative for that exposure?
gold_answer: Where the Authorised Person’s CR Exposure is to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank or the European Commission, it must apply a 0% risk weight to that CR Exposure [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16]. If, in addition, the Authorised Person wants to recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative for that exposure, it may do so only if the Credit Derivative is provided by one of the permitted types of entities [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b]. Those permitted providers are: a central government or central bank; an MDB; an International Organisation; a PSE; banks and Securities firms that qualify for inclusion in the bank asset class; or another entity that has an external credit assessment from a recognised credit rating agency that maps to a Credit Quality Grade 3 or better. In practice, this means the risk-weight outcome for the specified CR Exposures is fixed at 0%, but any Credit Derivative CRM recognition is still gated by who provides the derivative.
target_text: Multilateral development bank (MDB) asset class. An Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank or the European Commission.

question: When an Authorised Person is using the FCCA, how should eligible financial Collateral be defined by combining the general composition criteria (including instruments listed in the relevant rule, certain traded equity Securities, and qualifying Units in a Collective Investment Fund) with the specific exclusion for certain Capital instruments issued within the Authorised Person’s Financial Group and held as Collateral?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral is defined by starting with the categories that are permitted and then applying the stated carve-out. The permitted composition includes (i) any instrument listed in the relevant rule, (ii) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange, and (iii) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those traded equity Securities, provided a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments listed in the FCCA eligibility rule and the referenced rule. However, even if an instrument would otherwise fall within the “instrument listed” limb, it must be treated as ineligible if it is a T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person and held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral. This exclusion operates as a limitation on what can be counted as eligible financial Collateral under the FCCA definition. [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685] [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]
source_text: For the purposes of Rule 4.13.5 and 4.13.6, eligible financial Collateral excludes any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person, which is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity publishes Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, what must it say about the named Competent Person(s), and what consent must it have before it discloses the relevant statement and supporting information?
gold_answer: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, it must include clear information about the Competent Person(s) and also ensure the disclosure is authorised in the required way. On content, the disclosure must state that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). It must also state whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party; if the Competent Person is not, it must give the name of the Competent Person’s employer. In addition, it must state the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79]. Separately, the statement referred to in the framework must only be disclosed if the Petroleum Reporting Entity has the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) regarding the form and context in which the estimated resources/reserves and the supporting information are presented in the disclosure [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e].
source_text:
Competent Persons . The statement referred to in Rule 12.15.2:
(1)	must only be disclosed with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the estimated Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Prospective Resources, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure; and
(2)	only applies the first time a Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses original or updated estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves where:
(a)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves references the earlier disclosure containing the statements and consent referred to in Rules 12.15.2 and 12.15.3(1); and
(b)	the Petroleum Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure, and that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . A disclosure by a Petroleum Reporting Entity containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: What checks must a PFP Operator do on a PFP Prospect before it posts a financing proposal on a Private Financing Platform, and how long must it keep records showing those checks and related disclosures and communications?
gold_answer: Before the PFP Operator publishes a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, it must perform due diligence on the PFP Prospect to meet its disclosure requirements. This due diligence must include reviewing information the PFP Prospect provides about: (1) management details and background, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (2) the PFP Prospect’s background, including financial soundness, good standing and (if relevant) regulatory status; and (3) the financing proposal, to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the proposal is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. The PFP Operator must also keep evidence of what it did: for a minimum of six years it must maintain and keep a record of the due diligence it undertook, all disclosures made under the applicable disclosure rules, and all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].
source_text:
A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of:
(a)	all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2;
(b)	all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and
(c)	the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.
target_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity says its key economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, what does it have to add to its disclosure, and what warning applies if it has not signed any sensitive contracts supporting its price, capex, or opex assumptions?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity considers its material economic assumptions (used to determine forecast financial information) to be commercially sensitive, it must still disclose all material economic assumptions employed, and it must add a statement that the assumptions are commercially sensitive plus an explanation of the methodology used to determine those assumptions; it must also disclose all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. At the same time, it needs to be careful not to label information as commercially sensitive when it is not: where the Entity has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin its commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure assumptions, it would be difficult to justify treating information about those assumptions as commercially sensitive [#TGT:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95]. Practically, that means the Entity should only use the sensitivity statement when there is a real basis for it, and it should ensure the methodology explanation is consistent with the actual circumstances supporting (or not supporting) the sensitivity claim.

A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

If a Mining Reporting Entity, for example, has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin its commodity price, capital expenditure or operational expenditure assumptions, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions would be commercially sensitive.

question: Where an Authorised Person is authorised for custody or trustee services connected to a Fund or Investment Trust, what additional permission-based conditions would prevent it from being treated as Category 3B and instead place it in Category 1?
gold_answer: Category 3B is only available if the Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund) or Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust, and it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5; accordingly, if the firm meets Category 1 criteria, it is excluded from Category 3B by the express “does not meet” condition [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe]. Category 1 is met where the Financial Services Permission authorises the firm to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance clarifies that this authorisation is determinative even if other Regulated Activities are also authorised [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. Therefore, a custody/trustee-authorised firm would be prevented from being treated as Category 3B, and instead be treated as Category 1, if its permission also includes Accepting Deposits or Managing a PSIAu and it is not within Category 5, because that would cause it to meet Category 1 and fail the Category 3B exclusion test.

Category 3B
An Authorised Person is in Category 3B if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of:
(i)	Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund); or
(ii)	Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust; and
(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5.
Guidance
A Category 3B Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as Trustee of a Fund, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1, 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3B.

question: When preparing the annual report, what must the Board ensure regarding (i) a separate section on the audit committee’s work and (ii) explanations of safeguards for auditor independence in non-audit services, to evidence that Shareholders’ rights are effectively enabled and dialogue is promoted?
gold_answer: The Board must ensure that Shareholders’ rights are properly safeguarded through appropriate measures that enable Shareholders to exercise their rights effectively, promote effective dialogue with Shareholders and other key stakeholders as appropriate, and prevent any abuse or oppression of minority Shareholders [#TGT:07fe857d-d32b-4e85-a5b2-f6252690dd58]. In the annual report, this should be supported by transparency measures directed to Shareholders. Specifically, a separate section of the annual report should describe the work of the audit committee in discharging its responsibilities, giving Shareholders visibility into how the audit committee has performed its role and providing a concrete basis for engagement and scrutiny [#SRC:e6fc1de1-709b-4e05-b519-c6d344a0d34e]. In addition, the annual report should explain to Shareholders how auditor objectivity and independence is safeguarded where the auditor provides non-audit services, addressing a key area where Shareholders may have concerns and enabling more informed dialogue [#SRC:e6fc1de1-709b-4e05-b519-c6d344a0d34e]. These disclosures are not standalone; they should be treated as part of the Board’s overall measures to enable effective exercise of Shareholder rights and to reduce the risk of abuse or oppression, including of minority Shareholders [#TGT:07fe857d-d32b-4e85-a5b2-f6252690dd58].

Audit committee. A separate section of the annual report should describe the work of the audit committee in discharging its responsibilities. The annual report should also explain to Shareholders how, if the auditor provides non audit services, auditor objectivity and independence is safeguarded.
Principle 5 – Shareholder rights and effective dialogue
Rule 9.2.7
"The Board must ensure that the rights of Shareholders are properly safeguarded through appropriate measures that enable the Shareholders to exercise their rights effectively, promote effective dialogue with Shareholders and other key stakeholders as appropriate, and prevent any abuse or oppression of minority Shareholders."

The Board must ensure that the rights of Shareholders are properly safeguarded through appropriate measures that enable the Shareholders to exercise their rights effectively, promote effective dialogue with Shareholders and other key stakeholders as appropriate, and prevent any abuse or oppression of minority Shareholders.

question: When calculating CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person must deduct defined benefit pension fund assets; how must the Authorised Person determine the deductible amount where there is an associated deferred tax liability that could be extinguished on impairment or derecognition, and where the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use certain pension fund assets after giving adequate advance notification to the Regulator?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must deduct defined benefit pension fund assets from the calculation of its CET1 Capital as part of the required CET1 deductions framework [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. However, for purposes of determining the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets to be deducted, the deductible amount must be reduced in two specific ways: first, by the amount of any associated deferred tax liability that could be extinguished if the pension fund assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and second, by the amount of assets in the defined benefit pension fund that the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use, provided the Authorised Person has given the Regulator adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada]. Where assets are used to reduce the amount to be deducted on this basis, those assets must receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada].
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - defined benefit pension fund assets. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(d), the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets to be deducted from CET1 Capital must be reduced by the following:
(a)	the amount of any associated deferred tax liability which could be extinguished if the assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and
(b)	the amount of assets in the defined benefit pension fund which the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use where the Authorised Person has provided adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets to the Regulator. Those assets used to reduce the amount to be deducted must receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information and also reports Ore Reserves based on a Technical Study, what does it have to say about the economic assumptions it used, and what extra explanation is required if it says those assumptions are commercially sensitive?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity has to cover two connected disclosure areas: the assumptions behind its forecast financial information and the assumptions/outcomes behind the Technical Study used to support an Ore Reserves estimate. For the forecast financial information, it must include all material economic assumptions employed, and it must also include all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. If it believes the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it cannot simply withhold them; it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Separately, to reach the required level of confidence in the modifying factors used to determine an estimate of Ore Reserves, it will need to have carried out a relevant Technical Study (preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study), and it must disclose the key underlying assumptions and outcomes of that Technical Study [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464]. These requirements work together to make the economic basis and study basis transparent.

(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

Pursuant to Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), in order to achieve the required level of confidence in the modifying factors to determine an estimate of Ore Reserves, a Mining Reporting Entity will need to have carried out a relevant Technical Study (preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study ).  The key underlying assumptions and outcomes of the Technical Study are also to be disclosed.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation and relies on the carve-out that it is not required to follow the usual disclosure rule, what specific content must it still include in the disclosure to meet its mandatory requirements?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it may rely on a permission that it does not need to comply with the usual disclosure rule, but only on the condition that it complies with the specified alternative rules [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26]. Separately and in addition, the Mining Reporting Entity must ensure the disclosure itself contains a defined set of information and statements [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]. This includes a prominent statement explaining the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates, are not disclosed in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done sufficient work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, and that it is uncertain whether they will ever be able to be disclosed as such. The disclosure must also provide the sources and dates of the estimates; explain any Mineralisation categories used (including whether they differ from those in a Mining Reporting Standard); address relevance and reliability; summarise the evaluation/exploration work and key assumptions/methods; identify more recent relevant estimates/data; describe verification work needed, its timing and funding source; state the classification/reporting standard used; and include a named Competent Person statement attesting to the accuracy of information provided for specified items.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has already disclosed a Production Target with all the required assumptions and related details, when can it make a later Production Target disclosure without repeating those details, and what does it still need to include in that later disclosure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity’s first disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include specific content about how the Production Target was determined, including all material economic assumptions (or, if commercially sensitive, a statement and the methodology used), all other material assumptions, any statement that forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds, and the required breakdown of what proportions of the Production Target are based on reserves/resources, Inferred Mineral Resources, and any Exploration Target, together with the required statements for those categories [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. After that, a later disclosure about the same Production Target may omit the information that would otherwise need to be repeated, but only if it points back to the earlier disclosure that was compliant and it confirms that the material assumptions used in the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. Also, if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, or if it is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement for those situations, even though it can avoid re-stating the rest of the detailed required content [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: If Restricted Securities are issued and then a Takeover happens, what must a Listed Entity do within two Business Days to set up the holding lock, and when can the Regulator allow the party managing the holding lock to release it?
gold_answer: The Listed Entity has a timing and submission obligation tied to the holding lock: within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, it must obtain an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or another entity the Regulator considers suitable, and it must submit that undertaking to the Regulator [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. That undertaking must cover two key points: the entity will place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities it holds, and it will not release the holding lock unless it first has the Regulator’s prior written consent [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. Separately, in a Takeover or Merger scenario, the Regulator may consent to the party that is managing the holding lock releasing it, but only to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer or to transfer or cancel Securities under a Takeover [#SRC:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67]. This means the lock can be lifted only through the Regulator’s consent pathway, even when a corporate transaction creates a need to act.
source_text: Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock, to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover.
target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: When a law enforcement agency seeks a person’s interview answers for use in criminal proceedings against that person, what is the Investigator prohibited from doing, and how does the Regulator’s general practice of notifying the person fit into the permitted pathways for any disclosure?
gold_answer: Where a law enforcement agency requests a person’s answers from an interview conducted under the relevant compulsory questioning power for use in criminal proceedings against that person, the Investigator is prohibited from disclosing the statement to the law enforcement agency unless one of two conditions is met: the person consents to the disclosure, or the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff]. In parallel, when the Regulator receives such a request, the Regulator generally notifies the person concerned so the person has an opportunity to either consent to the disclosure or challenge the request, which operationally supports the consent-based exception and provides a procedural opportunity before disclosure occurs [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951]. However, that notification practice is qualified: it does not displace the prohibition on disclosure, and it may not apply where the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement, in which case disclosure may proceed under the legal compulsion exception [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff].
source_text: If the Regulator receives a request from a law enforcement agency for a person's answers in an interview conducted under section 206(1)(a) of the FSMR for the purpose of criminal proceedings against the person, the Regulator will, in accordance with section 207(2) of the FSMR, generally notify the person concerned of such request (so that the person has an opportunity to either consent to the disclosure or challenge the request), unless the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.
target_text:
The Investigator shall not disclose a statement made by a person in answer to any question asked pursuant to a requirement made of the person under section ‎206‎(1)‎(a) to any law enforcement agency for the purpose of criminal proceedings against the person unless—
(a)	the person consents to the disclosure; or
(b)	the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes, or is required to make, a disclosure under the Rules that contains statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets (including in offering and periodic reporting materials and online communications), what preparation standards must it follow, and how does the scope of covered disclosures determine when those standards apply?
gold_answer: Where a disclosure is made or required to be made under the Rules and it includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, the scope provision makes clear that the regime applies broadly across disclosure channels, including formal transaction documents and ongoing/public communications such as a Prospectus, Exempt Offer document, bidder’s and target’s statements, annual reports, financial statements, technical papers, presentations, and website content [#SRC:96612327-1f00-4faf-abc6-2c914cc73738]. Within that scope, the operative obligation is that a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing those types of statements must be prepared in accordance with both a Mining Reporting Standard and the chapter setting the disclosure requirements [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d]. Read together, the scope determines the trigger (any covered disclosure made or required under the Rules, regardless of medium), and the obligation determines the required method of preparation (alignment with the Mining Reporting Standard and the chapter). This means the Mining Reporting Entity should treat the preparation requirements as applying consistently whenever those statement types appear in any of the covered disclosure contexts.

Rule 11.2.1 applies to all disclosures made or required to be made under the Rules which include a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, including within a Prospectus, Exempt Offer document, bidder’s and target’s statements, annual reports, financial statements, technical papers, presentations, and website content and disclosures.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information that is derived from a Production Target, what must it include about the Production Target and the assumptions used, including how it must address any commercially sensitive material economic assumptions and the required breakdown and cautionary statements where the Production Target relies on Inferred Mineral Resources or an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: Where a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, it must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and it must also include the full set of information required for that Production Target disclosure.
