question: When an Authorised Person has failed to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, how must it treat proposed CET1 Capital-related actions that fall within the meaning of a distribution (including cash dividends, bonus Shares, or a redemption or purchase of its own Shares), and what calculation and notification steps must occur before any such action may be undertaken?
gold_answer: A distribution in connection with CET1 Capital is defined broadly to capture multiple forms of value transfer or capital reduction, including payment of cash dividends, distribution of fully or partly paid bonus Shares or other capital instruments, a redemption or purchase by an institution of its own Shares or other capital instruments, repayment of amounts paid up in connection with capital, and other items eligible for inclusion as CET1 Capital [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26]. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must first calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with the applicable rule and, until it has both calculated that amount and notified the Regulator, it must ensure it does not make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital (as defined) [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. This restriction also applies to creating an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, and to paying variable remuneration where the obligation was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement, as well as to making payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e].
target_text:
Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and
(b)	ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7:
(i)	make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or
(ii)	make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: If an Authorised Person is covered by this Appendix because it meets the stated criteria, when does it have to have a Trading Book based on what positions it holds, whether they are held for trading, and the dollar/percentage thresholds (including the last 12 months test)?
gold_answer: This Appendix applies to an Authorised Person that meets the referenced criteria and is thereby required to have a Trading Book [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d]. For an Authorised Person in that scope, it must have a Trading Book when the specific conditions in the obligation are met [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0]. The Authorised Person must have a Trading Book if it has positions that must be included in a Trading Book under Section A2.1 of App2, and those positions are held with trading intent under Rule A2.1.5. It also has to meet a size threshold based on the total value of positions eligible for inclusion in the Trading Book under those two conditions. That threshold is met if the value normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of its combined on and off balance sheet positions, or if it has exceeded $20 million or 6% of its combined on- and off balance sheet positions at any time in the preceding 12 month period. If these elements line up, the Trading Book is required.
source_text: This Appendix applies to an Authorised Person which meets the criteria in Rule 2.2.1 and is thereby required to have a Trading Book.
target_text:
An Authorised Person must have a Trading Book if:
(a)	it has positions that must be included in a Trading Book in accordance with Section A2.1 of App2;
(b)	those positions are held with trading intent in accordance with Rule A2.1.5; and
(c)	the total value of the positions eligible for inclusion in the Trading Book pursuant to (a) and (b):
(i)	normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of its combined on and off balance sheet positions; or
(ii)	has exceeded $20 million or 6% of its combined on- and off balance sheet positions at any time in the preceding 12 month period.

question: If a Listed Entity does not fully follow APP 4, what does it have to say in its annual financial report about the reasons and what it did instead, and what does the Regulator expect to be disclosed in the Prospectus and then later on?
gold_answer: When a Listed Entity has not fully adopted, or has only partially adopted, the best practice standards in APP 4, its annual financial report must clearly state whether APP 4 has been adopted and, if not fully, explain the reasons for the shortfall and describe what actions, if any, it has taken to achieve compliance to the extent the standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. The Regulator’s expectation complements this by focusing on disclosure continuity: if a Reporting Entity does not adopt APP 4 (or adopts it only partially), the Regulator expects the reasons and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the intended outcomes of the Corporate Governance Principles to be disclosed in the Prospectus and then continued thereafter through the applicable ongoing disclosure process [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e]. Together, these requirements mean the entity should provide consistent explanations and descriptions of substitute measures across both the initial Prospectus disclosure and the later annual reporting cycle, so stakeholders can understand both why APP 4 was not fully followed and how the entity is still working toward the governance outcomes.
source_text: Generally, if a Reporting Entity does not adopt the best practice standards set out in APP 4, or adopts them only partially, the Regulator would expect the reasons for doing so and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the outcomes intended by the Corporate Governance Principles to be disclosed in the Prospectus and thereafter pursuant to the Disclosure required under Rule 9.2.10. Any inaccurate or false representations would lead to the imposition of civil liability in accordance with section 70 of the FSMR.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: When a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, how must it deliver the refusal notification to the Customer, and what must the Governing Contract include to evidence the agreed means of communication for transmitting such notifications (including any technical requirements)?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider is required to notify of a refusal and must deliver that refusal notification in the manner that has been agreed for such communications [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. To ensure that this “agreed manner” is clear and operational for the Customer, the Governing Contract between the Third Party Provider and their Customers must, unless otherwise agreed in writing between the Third Party Provider and their Customer, set out the means of communication agreed between the parties for transmitting information or notifications, including any relevant technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software to receive them [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. In practice, this links the delivery obligation for refusal notifications to the contractually documented communication channel(s) and any prerequisites for receipt. The contract must also address the manner and frequency with which information under the relevant chapter is to be provided or made available, supporting consistent delivery of refusal notifications through the agreed communication arrangements [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].
source_text: Refusal of Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide the notification in the agreed manner of the refusal as set out in Rule 20.2.2.

question: What does a Mining Reporting Entity have to put in its first Rule 11.8.2 Production Target disclosure about assumptions and the make-up of the Production Target, and when can a later Production Target update leave out that detailed information if it points back to the earlier disclosure and confirms the assumptions have not materially changed (including any required prominent warning statements)?
gold_answer: In the first disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2, a Mining Reporting Entity must provide the key assumption and composition information supporting the Production Target. This includes all material economic assumptions used (or, if the Mining Reporting Entity considers them commercially sensitive, saying so and explaining the methodology used to determine them) and all other material assumptions utilised. If forecast commodity prices were used, it must state that the forecast pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds. It must also disclose the proportions of the Production Target based on the specified reserves/resources categories, including any Inferred Mineral Resources and any Exploration Target, and include the required statements about whether Inferred Mineral Resources and any Exploration Target are determining factors in viability and whether they feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan. Additional prominent, proximate cautionary statements (and other supporting items in the wholly-Inferred case) apply depending on whether the Production Target is wholly or partly based on Inferred Mineral Resources and/or partly based on an Exploration Target [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. A later disclosure about the Production Target may omit the otherwise-required detailed information if it references the earlier compliant disclosure, confirms the original material assumptions still apply and have not materially changed, and includes the required prominent cautionary statements where the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources and/or based in part on an Exploration Target [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: If an Authorised Person must use either the Simplified Approach or the Comprehensive Approach to recognise eligible financial Collateral, what counts as “eligible financial Collateral” when the Authorised Person uses the Comprehensive Approach, and how does that connect to the Simplified Approach’s focus on the composition of financial Collateral?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral by choosing and using either the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) or the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA) [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19]. If the Authorised Person uses the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral is defined to include: any instrument listed in the referenced list; any equity Security (including a convertible bond) traded on a regulated exchange; and certain Units in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those traded equity Securities, but only where the Unit price is publicly quoted daily and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments covered by the FCCA list and the referenced list [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]. This matters for the required choice of approach because the FCSA is described as adopting the treatment under the referenced list specifically “in relation to the composition of financial Collateral,” while the FCCA is the alternative approach and its definition expands and conditions what collateral is eligible under that approach [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19] [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85].
source_text:
An Authorised Person must use either the:
(a)	Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.5 in relation to the composition of financial Collateral; or
(b)	Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.6;
to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is making its first disclosure of Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, what Competent Person details must it state, and what extra steps are required when it later repeats or refers to the same results or estimates so the first-time rule still applies?
gold_answer: On the first time a Mining Reporting Entity discloses Exploration Results or original or updated estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, it must include specific Competent Person information in the disclosure: it must say the disclosure is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s); it must identify, for each Competent Person, whether they are an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, name the Competent Person’s employer; and it must state the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]. The “first-time only” scope is conditional: for later disclosures that refer to those same Exploration Results or estimates, the Mining Reporting Entity must (i) reference the earlier disclosure that complied, and (ii) confirm it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects what was included earlier; where the later disclosure relates to Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, it must also confirm the earlier material assumptions and technical parameters still apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d].
source_text:
Competent Persons . Rule 11.12.1 only applies the first time a Mining Reporting Entity discloses Exploration Results in accordance with Rule 11.4 or original or updated estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with Rules 11.5 or 11.6 provided that:
(1)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to those Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.12.1; and
(2)	the Mining Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure(s) and, in the case of estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure(s) continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: If an Authorised Person can provide custody for a Fund or act as trustee of an Investment Trust, when would it still be treated as Category 1 instead of Category 3B?
gold_answer: Even if an Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission authorises it to provide custody for a Fund or act as the Trustee of an Investment Trust, it will not be Category 3B if it meets the criteria of Category 1, because Category 3B requires that the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5 [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe]. Category 1 is triggered when the Financial Services Permission authorises the firm to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance explains that this authorisation is determinative of Category 1 even if the firm is also authorised for other Regulated Activities [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. So, a custody/trustee firm would still be treated as Category 1 if its permission also includes Accepting Deposits or Managing a PSIAu and it is not in Category 5, because that makes it meet Category 1 and therefore fail the “not Category 1” condition needed for Category 3B.
source_text:
Category 3B
An Authorised Person is in Category 3B if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of:
(i)	Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund); or
(ii)	Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust; and
(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5.
Guidance
A Category 3B Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as Trustee of a Fund, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1, 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3B.

question: What does an Authorised Person have to do to work out its countercyclical buffer and then keep the required buffer amount in CET1 Capital at all times?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must both calculate and maintain the buffer in CET1 Capital. On the calculation side, it must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by taking its Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures are located [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. That produces the required buffer amount for this buffer type. On the holding side, the Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, so it is not enough to compute the figure; the firm must continuously hold CET1 Capital in at least that amount once determined [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf]. Together, these requirements mean the firm must follow the specified method to quantify the countercyclical buffer and then ensure its CET1 Capital remains sufficient to cover the resulting required buffer amount on an ongoing basis.
source_text: An Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, as calculated in accordance with Rule 3.18.4.
target_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.

question: If an Authorised Person has foreign currency or gold risk under an Islamic Contract, can it skip calculating the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement, and what limits does it have to stay under?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person is exposed to the risk of foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract, it must calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement. But it can be allowed not to do that calculation if it meets two specific limits based on Capital Resources. First, its Foreign Currency business—worked out as the larger of (i) total gross long positions and (ii) total gross short positions across all Foreign Currencies—must not be more than 100% of its Capital Resources. Second, its overall net open position must not be more than 2% of its Capital Resources. So, even where the Authorised Person has the type of exposure that would normally trigger the calculation requirement, it may rely on the exemption only if it can show both that its Foreign Currency business stays within the 100% threshold and that its overall net open position stays within the 2% threshold. If either limit is exceeded, the exemption would not apply and the calculation obligation remains relevant. [#SRC:6a51fe1f-d0d3-42f6-b369-4e9345775696] [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97]
source_text: Market risk. An Authorised Person which is exposed to the risk of foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract, must calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with PRU Rule 5.6.2.
target_text:
An Authorised Person need not calculate a Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement if:
(a)	its Foreign Currency business, defined as the greater of the sum of its gross long positions and the sum of its gross short positions in all Foreign Currencies, does not exceed 100% of Capital Resources as defined in Chapter 3; and
(b)	its overall net open position as defined in Rule A6.4.4 does not exceed 2% of its Capital Resources as defined in Chapter 3.

question: How must a PFP Operator align its pre-publication review of a PFP Prospect and the financing proposal with its obligation to publish information to PFP Clients about the criteria for accepting proposals and the details of each financing proposal made available on the Private Financing Platform?
gold_answer: A PFP Operator must conduct due diligence on a PFP Prospect before publishing a financing proposal relating to that PFP Prospect, and that due diligence must include reviewing management information (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers), reviewing the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status where relevant), and reviewing the financing proposal to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the proposal’s content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. In addition to performing that pre-publication review, the PFP Operator must ensure that PFP Clients can access published information on the Private Financing Platform it operates, including the details of any financing proposal published and the criteria and methodology for accepting a PFP Prospect’s financing proposal for publication [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]. Practically, the due diligence review of the PFP Prospect and the proposal provides the basis for the PFP Operator to publish proposal details responsibly, while the published acceptance criteria and methodology explain to PFP Clients how proposals are screened for publication. These obligations operate together: the PFP Operator must both do the substantive review before publication and disclose, on-platform, how proposals are selected and what proposal information is being presented to clients.
source_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: What does the PFP Operator have to review about a PFP Prospect and its financing proposal before publishing, and what information must it then publish to PFP Clients about the proposal and how it decides to accept proposals for publication?
gold_answer: Before publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence on the PFP Prospect. This includes reviewing the management’s details and background (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers), reviewing the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status if relevant), and reviewing the financing proposal to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the proposal is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. After (and alongside) that work, the PFP Operator must ensure that information is published on the Private Financing Platform it operates and is available to PFP Clients. This published information must include the details of any financing proposal published on the platform, and it must also include the criteria and methodology for accepting a PFP Prospect’s financing proposal for publication on the platform [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]. In combination, these requirements mean the PFP Operator must both do a substantive review before publication and clearly disclose to PFP Clients what proposal details are being shown and how the platform decides which PFP Prospect proposals are accepted for publication.

question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business prepares its Resolution Pack, what record must it include to evidence compliance with the requirement that, before depositing Client Money with a Third-Party Agent, it has obtained a written acknowledgment that the Third-Party Agent cannot combine the relevant Client Account with any other account?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must include in its Resolution Pack the record evidencing the Third-Party Agent’s written acknowledgment obtained before any deposit of Client Money into a Client Account established with that Third-Party Agent. The Resolution Pack is expressly required to contain the records relating to the assessment of appropriateness of the Third-Party Agent and the Third-Party Agent’s acknowledgment in respect of Client Money [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. That acknowledgment must cover, among other protections, that all Money standing to the credit of the account is held by the Authorised Person on behalf of its Clients and that the Third-Party Agent is not entitled to combine the account with any other account (and also cannot assert various rights such as set-off or security interests against Money in the account for sums owed by the Authorised Person) [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9]. Accordingly, the Resolution Pack should contain the written acknowledgment itself (or a complete record of it) demonstrating that the non-combination restriction and related safeguards were obtained in writing prior to depositing Client Money.
target_text: Before depositing Client Money in a Client Account established with a Third-Party Agent, it must obtain a written acknowledgment from the Third-Party Agent stating that all Money standing to the credit of the account is held by the Authorised Person on behalf of its Clients and that the Third-Party Agent is not entitled to combine the account with any other account, or exercise any charge, mortgage, security, lien, right of set-off or combination or counterclaim against Money in that account in respect of any sum owed to it by the Authorised Person.

question: If a Listed Entity has already made a deal to issue Equity Securities without getting holder approval first, when can that deal later be treated as approved, and how does that affect whether the Listed Entity is still prohibited from issuing more than the maximum number allowed without approval?
gold_answer: The Listed Entity is prohibited from issuing, or agreeing to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the formula unless it has approval from the holders of Ordinary Securities [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. If the Listed Entity made an issue (or agreement to issue) without the required approval, it can later be treated as if it had been made with approval, but only if all of the following happen: the issue or agreement did not exceed the relevant limit, the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities subsequently approve it, and the Securities are actually issued within three months after that approval date [#SRC:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6]. This matters for the “maximum number” prohibition because the Target’s calculation subtracts “Relevant Issues” (prior issues in the last 12 months) but does not count issues that were made with holder approval, and it also allows certain approved (or taken to have been approved) agreements and issues to be included in the Base Amount in specified situations. So, getting subsequent approval on time can change how that earlier issue is counted in the formula and therefore whether more issuance would breach the prohibition.
source_text:
Subsequent approval of an issue of Securities. An issue of, or agreement to issue, Securities made without approval under Rule 9.7.1 is treated as having been made with approval for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1 if:
(1)	the issue or agreement did not exceed the limit in Rule 9.7.1;
(2)	the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities subsequently approve it; and
(3)	the Securities are issued within three months of the date of the approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: If the Listing Authority’s enquiry leads it to think the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not exempt, and it believes the information should have been disclosed earlier, what does an ‘aware letter’ usually ask the Reporting Entity to confirm, and when is the Listing Authority allowed to send that letter (instead of only asking for a disclosure)?
gold_answer: If, following an enquiry into complaints or allegations of non-compliance, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within an exemption from disclosure, it will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter; and if the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an ‘aware letter’ (or take other relevant action) [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944]. An ‘aware letter’ generally uses a standard template and typically identifies the information in question and the date it was Disclosed, then asks the Reporting Entity whether it believes the information is Inside Information. If the Reporting Entity says “yes,” it is asked to confirm when it first became aware of the Inside Information (including the time and circumstances) and, if it was aware before the letter date, why it did not Disclose earlier or request a Trading Halt or Suspension, including specific comment on how the disclosure obligation applied. If it says “no,” it must confirm the basis for not treating the information as Inside Information. The letter also asks the Reporting Entity to confirm it is in compliance with the Markets Rules, particularly the disclosure obligation [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28].
source_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Complaints or allegations of non-compliance by Reporting Entities
If, as a result of the enquiry, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within exemption from Disclosure provided by Rule 7.2.2, the Listing Authority will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1.  If the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an ‘aware letter’ (see paragraphs 187 to 189 above), or take other relevant action.
target_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Aware Letters
Similar to a MAQ Letter, ‘aware letters’ tend to follow a standard template.  Generally, they will identify the information in question and the relevant date it was Disclosed, and ask the following questions:

(i)	Does the Reporting Entity believe the information identified in the letter to be Inside Information (being information that a reasonable person would expect to have a significant effect on the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities)?

(ii)	If the answer to question i) is “yes”, please confirm the following:

i.	When did the Reporting Entity first become aware of the Inside Information identified in the letter? Please include details of the relevant time and circumstances of the Reporting Entity becoming aware of the [key contents of the Inside Information]?

ii.	If the Reporting Entity was aware of the [key contents of the Inside Information] prior to the date of this letter, please advise why the Reporting Entity did not Disclose the Inside Information or request a Trading Halt or Suspension at an earlier time?  Please comment specifically on the application of Rule 7.2.1.

(iii)	If the answer to question i) is “no”, please confirm the basis on which the Reporting Entity does not consider the information to be Inside Information?

(iv)	Please confirm that the Reporting Entity is in compliance with the Markets Rules and, in particular, Rule 7.2.1.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity withholds detail of material economic assumptions on the basis of commercial sensitivity, what must it include in its disclosure to substantiate that position, and how should it assess whether the claim is credible where no commercially sensitive contracts underpin commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure assumptions?
gold_answer: Where a Mining Reporting Entity treats material economic assumptions used to determine forecast financial information as commercially sensitive, its disclosure must still include all material economic assumptions employed, and—specifically for any assumptions it considers commercially sensitive—a clear statement that the assumptions are commercially sensitive together with an explanation of the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions, as well as all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. In applying that requirement, the Entity should be careful not to assert commercial sensitivity where it is not genuinely the case: if it has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin its commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure assumptions, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions would be commercially sensitive [#TGT:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95]. Accordingly, the Entity should align its sensitivity statement and methodology explanation with the factual basis for sensitivity, and avoid using sensitivity as a blanket rationale where the underlying assumptions are not contractually or otherwise commercially constrained.
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Mining Reporting Entities need to be careful not to claim that information is commercially sensitive when this is not the case.  If a Mining Reporting Entity, for example, has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin its commodity price, capital expenditure or operational expenditure assumptions, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions would be commercially sensitive.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, under what conditions may a subsequent disclosure about those same Non-Equivalent Estimates omit the detailed content otherwise required in the original disclosure, and what minimum statement must still be presented prominently and close to the estimates?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that is disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation must ordinarily include the full set of specified content in its disclosure, including a prominent and proximate statement addressing the nature and limitations of the Non-Equivalent Estimates, along with other prescribed supporting information (such as sources/dates, relevance, reliability, summaries of work and assumptions, and verification plans) [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]. However, where the Mining Reporting Entity has previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates in a manner that complied with those requirements, a later disclosure made in respect of the same Non-Equivalent Estimates is permitted to omit the information otherwise required, provided three conditions are met: it must reference the earlier compliant disclosure; it must include the Mining Reporting Entity’s confirmation that the earlier compliant information continues to apply and that there is no new material information or data affecting reliability/interpretation or the entity’s ability to verify the estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard; and it must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the same matters as the original prominent statement requirement [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4].
source_text:
If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure:
(1)	references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule;
(2)	contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that:
(a)	the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and
(b)	there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the:
(i)	reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or
(ii)	Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(3)	includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

question: In what circumstances is the Regulator permitted to refuse to grant an application for registration, and how does that permission apply both to a Fund generally and specifically to a Public Fund?
gold_answer: Across both passages, the Regulator is permitted to refuse to grant an application for registration when a specific condition is not met: the Regulator is not satisfied that the relevant requirements have been met. In the SOURCE, this permission applies to an application for the registration of a Fund, and the refusal power is triggered if the Regulator is not satisfied that the requirements referred to in the referenced requirements provision have been met [#SRC:4881ebd8-8cd6-4bd0-b0fe-19b9b9a421bf]. In the TARGET, the same refusal permission is stated in the context of an Application for registration of a Public Fund, again conditioned on the Regulator not being satisfied that the requirements referred to in the same referenced requirements provision have been met [#TGT:84155043-3488-4333-94e3-f4dae46b6df3]. Read together, the common compliance implication is that an Applicant should expect the Regulator to assess whether the applicable requirements have been met before granting registration, and that a failure to satisfy the Regulator on those requirements can result in rejection of the application, whether the application concerns a Fund generally or a Public Fund specifically.
source_text: Under Section 109 of the FSMR, the Regulator may refuse to grant an application for the registration of a Fund if it is not satisfied that the requirements referred to in Section 107 of the FSMR have been met.
target_text:
Rejection of an Application
The Regulator may refuse to grant an Application for registration of a Public Fund if it is not satisfied that the requirements referred to in section ‎107 have been met.

question: When a substantial additional regulatory burden arises for FSRA and the Regulator expects substantial additional costs or effort in handling an application, authorisation, filing, or ongoing supervision, may the Regulator require a Person (including an Applicant/Authorised Person) to pay supplementary or additional fees, and what practical step is recommended to manage the fee implications?
gold_answer: Yes. The SOURCE establishes that FSRA reserves the right to impose additional fees where a “substantial additional” regulatory burden is imposed on FSRA, and it highlights that such circumstances can include a migration of an MTF to become a conventional “Securities” Recognised Investment Exchange, indicating that fee impacts may arise from increased regulatory work [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc]. The TARGET complements this by permitting the Regulator to require a Person to pay a supplementary fee when it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision, which aligns with the SOURCE’s concept of additional burden translating into additional fee recovery [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Taken together, the framework supports the Regulator’s ability to levy extra charges in high-effort or high-cost cases affecting Applicants/Authorised Persons. As a practical compliance step, FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person discuss fee implications with FSRA as early as practicable, so potential supplementary/additional fees can be anticipated and managed in advance [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc].
source_text:
FEES
Cumulative application of Fees
Pursuant to FEES Rule 1.2.4, the FSRA reserves its right to impose additional fees in circumstances where a ‘substantial additional’ regulatory burden is imposed on FSRA. In such circumstances, including the migration of an MTF to become a conventional ‘Securities’ Recognised Investment Exchange, the FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person discuss FEE implications with the FSRA as early as practicable.
target_text:
Supplementary fees
The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing or when conducting on-going supervision.

question: When a Recognised Investment Exchange is permitted by the FSRA to operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or MTF using Virtual Assets under its Recognition Order, what additional market operation must it ensure in parallel to satisfy the Recognition Requirements?
gold_answer: If a Recognised Investment Exchange is permitted by the FSRA, and subject to the stated conditions, to operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or an MTF using Virtual Assets under its Recognition Order, that permission does not displace the baseline operational requirement that applies when it is operating an MTF or an OTF. In that case, the Recognised Investment Exchange must also operate a market that complies with the Recognition Requirements, meaning it needs to maintain a compliant market alongside the operation of the MTF or OTF (including where those facilities are operated separately and may involve Virtual Assets). Practically, the permission to add or separate facilities (including an MTF using Virtual Assets) is conditional and scoped, and the obligation is cumulative: operating the MTF or OTF triggers the requirement to also operate a Recognition Requirements-compliant market. This ensures that, even where additional trading facilities are introduced under the Recognition Order, the Recognised Investment Exchange continues to operate a market meeting the Recognition Requirements as required [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d] while relying on the FSRA-permitted ability to operate the separate facilities [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0].
source_text:
MULTILATERAL TRADING FACILITIES AND VIRTUAL ASSETS
Recognised Investment Exchanges Operating an MTF using Virtual Assets
This means that a Recognised Investment Exchange (in addition to operating markets relating to the trading of Financial Instruments (including Digital Securities) can, where permitted by the FSRA and subject to MIR Rule 3.4.2, operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or MTF using Virtual Assets under its Recognition Order.
target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange operating an MTF or an OTF, must also operate a market that complies with the Recognition Requirements.

question: For an Authorised Person, how does the scope of its Financial Services Permission determine whether it is classified in Category 1 versus Category 3B, and what exclusionary category tests must be satisfied in each case?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person’s category turns on which Regulated Activities its Financial Services Permission authorises and on specified exclusion tests. For Category 1, the permission must authorise the firm to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and the firm must not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance emphasises that this specific authorisation is determinative even if the firm is also authorised for other Regulated Activities [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. By contrast, Category 3B applies where the permission authorises one or more of the Regulated Activities of Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund) or Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5; the guidance similarly notes that the custody-for-a-Fund or trustee authorisation, together with the absence of authorisation for certain other activities, is determinative even if other activities are also authorised [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe].
source_text:
Category 3B
An Authorised Person is in Category 3B if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of:
(i)	Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund); or
(ii)	Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust; and
(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5.
Guidance
A Category 3B Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as Trustee of a Fund, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1, 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3B.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: If the Investigator sends a written notice telling the Person Under Investigation (or someone else) to let the Investigator into their business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy Documents, does the Investigator have to warn them ahead of time that an inspection is coming?
gold_answer: No. The Investigator may, by written notice, require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to permit the Investigator to enter that person’s business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy Documents there [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Separately, for the power to enter premises and inspect and copy documents, the Investigator will give written notice of the exercise of that power, but there is no requirement for the Investigator to give that notice in advance [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980]. This means the Investigator can carry out an inspection without giving prior warning, even though written notice is still part of how the power is exercised [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980]. The passage also explains why advance notice might be withheld: there may be circumstances where the Investigator considers it appropriate not to provide prior notice, such as where giving prior notice may prejudice the investigation [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980]. Taken together, the Investigator can require access by written notice and still choose not to provide advance notice of the inspection itself [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].
source_text: Power to enter premises and inspect and copy documents . The Investigator will give written notice of the exercise of the power to enter business premises under section 206(1)(e) of FSMR. However, there is no requirement for an Investigator to give notice of the exercise of this power in advance. There may be circumstances when the Investigator considers it appropriate not to provide prior notice of an inspection, for example where the provision of prior notice may prejudice the investigation.

question: Where a Listed Entity has not fully adopted, or has only partially adopted, the best practice standards in APP 4, what must its annual financial report state and explain about the reasons and any alternative actions taken, and how does this align with the Regulator’s expectation for disclosure in the Prospectus and subsequent disclosures?
gold_answer: If a Listed Entity has not fully adopted, or has only partially adopted, the best practice standards in APP 4, its annual financial report must (i) state whether those standards have been adopted, and (ii) where adoption is incomplete, explain why full adoption did not occur and what actions, if any, have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent the standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. This annual reporting obligation aligns with the Regulator’s broader disclosure expectation that, when a Reporting Entity does not adopt the APP 4 best practice standards (or adopts them only partially), the reasons for doing so and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the intended outcomes should be disclosed in the Prospectus and then continued thereafter through the relevant ongoing disclosure channel [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e]. Read together, the two passages require a coherent narrative across initial offering disclosure and ongoing annual reporting: the entity must be transparent about the rationale for any deviation from APP 4 and must describe the substitute steps or measures it has adopted to pursue the Corporate Governance Principles’ outcomes, updated through annual compliance reporting.
source_text: Generally, if a Reporting Entity does not adopt the best practice standards set out in APP 4, or adopts them only partially, the Regulator would expect the reasons for doing so and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the outcomes intended by the Corporate Governance Principles to be disclosed in the Prospectus and thereafter pursuant to the Disclosure required under Rule 9.2.10. Any inaccurate or false representations would lead to the imposition of civil liability in accordance with section 70 of the FSMR.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: If a PFP Operator reviews a financing proposal to make sure it is clear and not misleading, what other due diligence items must it review, and what records must it keep for at least six years?
gold_answer: When the PFP Operator is preparing to publish a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, it must do due diligence on the PFP Prospect to satisfy its disclosure requirements. Beyond reviewing the financing proposal to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, it is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading, the due diligence must also include reviewing information provided by the PFP Prospect on management (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers) and on the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing and any relevant regulatory status) [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. The PFP Operator must then keep records to show what it did: for a minimum of six years it must maintain and keep a record of the due diligence undertaken, all disclosures made under the applicable disclosure rules, and all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].
source_text:
A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of:
(a)	all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2;
(b)	all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and
(c)	the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.
target_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: Can the Regulator make Rules that tell a Reporting Entity what Corporate Governance standards it must follow (including for the board of Directors, Controllers, and employees), and how should the Reporting Entity use its annual report explanation to show it meets the long‑term, prudent management goal for the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders?
gold_answer: Yes. Read together, the passages indicate that the Regulator has permission to set detailed Corporate Governance requirements by Rules and that those requirements are aimed at ensuring a Reporting Entity’s governance supports prudent and sound management over the long term in the interests of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. The SOURCE states that the Regulator is entitled to enact rules requiring a Reporting Entity to have an adequate Corporate Governance framework to promote prudent and sound long‑term management, and it adds that, in the annual report explanation, a Reporting Entity should aim to illustrate how its actual practices achieve compliance with the outcomes intended by the relevant framework and Principles, thereby contributing to prudent and sound management [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1]. The TARGET then clarifies what the Regulator may prescribe by Rules for that requirement: Corporate Governance principles and standards applying to a Reporting Entity, including requirements for its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees, or any other person as appropriate, plus requirements on fair treatment of Shareholders and provisions to address conflicts of interests [#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d].
source_text: General. Section 73(2) of the FSMR provides that the Regulator is entitled to enact rules requiring a Reporting Entity to have a Corporate Governance framework which is adequate to promote prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity in the long term interest of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. Accordingly, in providing its explanation in the annual report as noted in 2, a Reporting Entity should aim to illustrate how its actual practices achieve compliance with the outcomes intended by section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles, and thereby contribute to prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity.
target_text:
For the purposes of the requirement in subsection ‎(1), the Regulator may by Rules prescribe—
(a)	Corporate Governance principles and standards that apply to a Reporting Entity, including any requirements applicable to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees or any other person as appropriate;
(b)	requirements relating to fair treatment of Shareholders; and
(c)	provisions to address conflicts of interests.
